block.p: The Economy
Better-than-expected January sales were reported by the nation's largest store chains, but the results stood out against extremely low sales a year earlier. [ D1. ]
Treasury Secretary Brady all but abandoned the Administration's recommendations to overhaul the banking system by throwing his support behind a more modest approach. [ D1. ]
The Economy
Better-than-expected January sales were reported by the nation's largest store chains, but the results stood out against extremely low sales a year earlier. [ D1. ]
Treasury Secretary Brady all but abandoned the Administration's recommendations to overhaul the banking system by throwing his support behind a more modest approach. [ D1. ]
The Senate voted to streamline licensing procedures for new nuclear power plants. [ D2. ]
A hearing on the plan to overhaul the Government securities market degenerated into personal bickering. [ D2. ]
Barbara H. Franklin, Bush's nominee to become Commerce Secretary, said at her Senate confirmation hearing that a conflict of interest would bar from some areas. [ D4. ]
Factory orders in December were sharply lower and jobless claims were stagnant in late January, the Government said. [ D17. ]
The nation's luxury-boat builders got some good news when Bush asked Congress to repeal the luxury tax on yachts. [ D1. ]
The Administration supported a Senate action to speed up the phase-out of chemicals that damage the ozone layer. [ A1. ]
Saying it would make quality medical care affordable for all, Bush proposed several tax incentives and other changes. [ A1. ]
Loan frauds that dangle the prospect of quick cash for a fee are a fast-growing category of consumer complaints. [ A1. ]
Tax and growth legislation will be controlled by closed-door politics, not open arguments. Washington Talk. [ A13. ] Companies
Salomon reported a $29 million quarterly loss, capping a tumultuous year that began with solid profits and ended with a shift toward conservative management following the scandal. [ D1. ]
Chrysler posted a small quarterly profit, overcoming huge losses earlier last year, thanks to a one-time gain from the sale of its interest in a venture with Mitsubishi. [ D1. ]
Continental Airlines filed a reorganization plan in which its major unsecured creditors will get stock. [ D3. ]
Owens-Corning Fiberglas said it took an $800 million charge to cover uninsured asbestos liabilities. [ D3. ]
The Racing Times closed. No buyer was found to rescue it from the upheaval that has torn apart the Maxwell empire. [ D18. ]
I.B.M. is considering selling two circuit-board assembly operations to Solectron, a maker of electronic products. [ D3. ] International
In the debate over opening world markets to American goods, the U.S. does not come to the table with clean hands. [ A1. ]
Three European countries have proposed to their Western allies that they drop virtually all restrictions on exporting civilian telecommunications gear. [ D1. ]
Mazda introduced its new 626 compact, calling it the first "foreign" brand car to be classified as domestic for purposes of Federal fuel-efficiency regulations. [ D5. ] Markets
Stocks were mixed in heavy, choppy trading. The Dow lost 2.01, to 3,255.59. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury securities dipped. [ D13. ]
The dollar settled mostly lower in quiet trading. [ D14. ] Platinum futures advanced strongly. [ D14. ] Today's Columns
Creating free markets in Russia and other poor countries may do more to slow global warming than any measures rich countries are likely to adopt, a study says. Economic Scene. [ D2. ]
Many German steel companies are expected to lose money on steelmaking operations this year. Market Place. [ D6. ]
Advertisers with endorsement pacts with Magic Johnson struggle to define their ties to him. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [ D18. ]
